{
  "article_text": [
    "surfaces generated by simplest curves ( lines and circles ) are popular subject in pure mathematics and have applications to design and architecture @xcite . if a surface contains two such curves through each point then we get a mesh on the surface .",
    "famous examples of such meshes are v.  g.  shukhov s hyperboloid structures .",
    "a natural question is which other surfaces can be constructed from straight and circular beams .",
    "it is well - known that a surface containing two lines through each point ( _ doubly ruled surface _ ) must be a quadric . in this paper",
    "we show that a smooth surface containing both a line and a circle through each point still must be a quadric ; see figure  [ fig1 ] to the left . by a _",
    "smooth surface _ we mean the image of an injective @xmath0 map @xmath1 with nowhere vanishing differential .    [ ruled ] if through each point of a smooth surface in @xmath2 one can draw both a straight line segment and a circular arc transversal to each other and fully contained in the surface ( and continuously depending on the point ) then the surface is a piece of either a one - sheeted hyperboloid , or a quadratic cone , or an elliptic cylinder , or a plane .    ) , we prove that the planes of the generating circles are parallel ( lemma  [ parallel ] ) and intersect the surface only at the points of the circles ( lemma  [ circleonly ] ) .",
    "right : a cyclide contains several circles through each point .",
    "finding all surfaces with this property is a challenging open problem .",
    "so far we prove that a surface with @xmath3 circles through each point is a cyclide ( theorem  [ 3families ] ) .",
    ", title=\"fig:\",scaledwidth=15.0% ] ) , we prove that the planes of the generating circles are parallel ( lemma  [ parallel ] ) and intersect the surface only at the points of the circles ( lemma  [ circleonly ] ) .",
    "right : a cyclide contains several circles through each point .",
    "finding all surfaces with this property is a challenging open problem .",
    "so far we prove that a surface with @xmath3 circles through each point is a cyclide ( theorem  [ 3families ] ) .",
    ", title=\"fig:\",scaledwidth=33.0% ]    in what follows a line ( circle ) continuously depending on a real parameter is called a _",
    "family _ of lines ( circles ) .",
    "although the proof is rather elementary , theorem  [ ruled ] is more tricky than the classical description of doubly ruled surfaces .",
    "let us illustrate the difference .",
    "first , the classical result does not really require @xmath4 lines through _ each _ point : a surface covered by @xmath5 family of lines and containing just @xmath6 more lines intersecting them all must already be a quadric .",
    "second , the classical result remains true in _ complex _ 3-space .",
    "however , similar generalizations of theorem  [ ruled ] are far from being true ; see examples  [ ex1][ex5 ] below .",
    "the next natural problem , which seems to be still open ( and is going to be studied in detail in a subsequent publication ) , is to describe all surfaces containing several circles through each point .",
    "an example of such surface is a _ cyclide _",
    ", i.e. , the surface given by the equation of the form @xmath7 where @xmath8 are constants and @xmath9 is a polynomial of degree at most @xmath4 ; see figure  [ fig1 ] to the right .",
    "such a surface is also called a _ darboux cyclide _ , not to be confused with a",
    "_ dupin cyclide _ being a particular case .",
    "this class of surfaces appears in different branches of mathematics @xcite .",
    "an introduction to cyclides and circles on them can be found in the work of pottmann et  al .",
    "any cyclide ( besides some degenerate cases ) contains at least @xmath4 circles through each point  @xcite .",
    "conversely , a surface containing @xmath4 cospherical or @xmath4 orthogonal circles through each point must be a cyclide ; see theorem  [ cospherical ] below ( taken from @xcite ) and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorems  1 and  2 ) .",
    "however , this is not true without the assumption of either cosphericity or orthogonality ; see example  [ ex4 ] below .",
    "a torus is an example of a cyclide with @xmath3 circles through each point : a meridian , a parallel , and @xmath4 villarceau circles .",
    "there are cyclides with @xmath10 circles through each point  @xcite .",
    "we give a short proof of the takeuchi theorem @xcite stating that a surface with @xmath11 circles through each point must be a sphere ( theorem  [ takeuchi ] below ) , and we generalize an old darboux result that a surface with sufficiently many circles through each point is a cyclide ( theorem  [ 3families ] below ) .",
    "further generalizations concern _ conic bundles _ , in particular , surfaces containing a conic through each point",
    ". surfaces containing both a line and a conic through each point were classified by brauner @xcite .",
    "such a surface has degree at most @xmath3 .",
    "notice that it is much more difficult to deduce theorem  [ ruled ] from this classification than to prove theorem  [ ruled ] itself .",
    "surfaces containing several conics through each point were classified by schicho @xcite .",
    "such surfaces have degree at most @xmath12 and admit a biquadratic rational parametrization . _",
    "webs _ of circles and conics are discussed in @xcite .",
    "the paper is organized as follows . in section",
    "[ sec : proofs ] we prove theorem  [ ruled ] . in section  [ sec : variations ] we state and prove some related results mentioned above .",
    "throughout this section we work over the field of complex numbers except otherwise is explicitly indicated .",
    "denote by @xmath13 the @xmath6-dimensional complex projective space with homogeneous coordinates @xmath14 .",
    "the _ infinitely distant plane _ is the plane @xmath15 .",
    "the _ absolute conic _ is given by the equations @xmath16 , @xmath15 .",
    "a ( _ nondegenerate _ ) _ complex circle _ is an irreducible conic in @xmath13 having two distinct common points with the absolute conic . clearly , a circle in @xmath2 is a subset of a complex circle .",
    "the set of projective lines in @xmath13 can be naturally identified with the _ plcker quadric _ @xmath17 in @xmath18 : the line passing through points @xmath19 and @xmath20 is identified with the point @xmath21 .",
    "let @xmath22 be a surface covered by a family of real line segments and a family of real circular arcs simultaneously .",
    "the complex lines and complex circles containing the members of these families are called _ generating lines _ and _ generating circles _ , respectively .",
    "hereafter assume that @xmath22 is not a plane .",
    "[ parallel ] the planes of the generating circles are parallel to each other .    to prove the lemma",
    ", we need several auxiliary claims . the first one is essentially known .",
    "[ harris ] let @xmath23 be pairwise distinct irreducible algebraic curves .",
    "the set @xmath24 of all the lines passing through the curve @xmath25 is an algebraic subset of @xmath17 .",
    "the set @xmath26 of all the lines passing through each of the curves @xmath27 but not passing through their intersection @xmath28 is a piece of a @xmath4-dimensional algebraic surface in @xmath17 .",
    "the union @xmath29 of all the lines passing through each of the curves @xmath30 but not passing through their pairwise intersections is a piece of an algebraic surface in @xmath13 .    moreover , one can check that @xmath31 and @xmath32 are quasi - projective varieties .",
    "\\(1 ) the set @xmath33 of pairs @xmath34 such that the point @xmath35 belongs to the line @xmath36 is algebraic .",
    "the set @xmath37 is the image of the projection @xmath38 and by   is also algebraic .",
    "\\(2 ) consider the polynomial map @xmath39 taking a pair of points @xmath40 to the line passing through @xmath35 and @xmath41 .",
    "then @xmath31 is the image of this map .",
    "the map @xmath42 is a finite covering by a piece of a 2-dimensional irreducible surface .",
    "thus @xmath31 is a piece of a 2-dimensional irreducible algebraic surface @xmath43 .",
    "( 3 ) by ( 2 ) the set @xmath44 is a ( possibly empty ) piece of the algebraic set @xmath45 . since for each @xmath46",
    "the surface @xmath47 is 2-dimensional and irreducible it follows that @xmath48 . if @xmath49 then @xmath50 and by   it follows that @xmath51 is a piece of a plane . if @xmath52 then @xmath51 is a piece of an algebraic surface as the image of the projection @xmath53 .",
    "figure2.png ( 12 , 36)@xmath54 ( 63 , 60 ) @xmath55 ( 30 , 49 ) @xmath35 ( 45 , 66 ) @xmath25 ( 51 , 59 ) @xmath56 ( 55 , 47 ) @xmath57    [ algebraic ] the surface @xmath22 is contained in an irreducible ruled algebraic surface @xmath58 .",
    "the family of generating lines is a piece of an irreducible algebraic curve in @xmath17 .",
    "take a point @xmath59 ; see figure  [ cl2_3 ] .",
    "draw a circular arc @xmath60 through the point @xmath35 .",
    "draw the line segments in @xmath55 from our continuous family through each point of @xmath25 .",
    "since the drawn segments are transversal to @xmath25 , the circular arcs contained in @xmath55 form a continuous family , and @xmath55 is smooth it follows that there are arcs @xmath61 ( sufficiently close to @xmath25 ) which intersect each of the drawn segments .",
    "let @xmath62 be the complex circles in @xmath13 containing the arcs @xmath63 .",
    "let @xmath64 be the union of those drawn segments , whose lines do not pass through the intersections @xmath65 , @xmath66 , @xmath67 . by construction @xmath68 .",
    "thus by claim  [ harris](3 ) the collar @xmath69 is a piece of an algebraic surface .",
    "take @xmath70 to be an irreducible component of the surface containing a closed 2-dimensional subset of the initial surface @xmath55 including the point @xmath35 .",
    "( if there are no such components , e.g. , @xmath71 , then the drawn segments sufficiently close to the point @xmath35 form a quadratic cone with vertex at one of the intersection points of the circles @xmath62 ; in this case set @xmath72 to be this cone . )",
    "the algebraic surface @xmath73 does not depend on the point @xmath35 because the smooth surface @xmath22 can not jump from one irreducible algebraic surface to another .    by claim",
    "[ harris](2 ) the lines containing the drawn segments form a piece of the algebraic set @xmath74 .",
    "since @xmath55 is not a plane it follows that the latter set is an algebraic curve ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 1 , @xmath75 ) .",
    "take @xmath76 to be an irreducible component of this curve containing the lines sufficiently close to the point @xmath35 .",
    "clearly , the union of the lines of the whole curve @xmath77 covers @xmath70 , i.e. , @xmath72 is ruled .",
    "it remains to show that the curve @xmath77 does not depend on the choice of the point @xmath35 .",
    "indeed , assume that the generating lines through a neighborhood of another point @xmath78 form a curve @xmath79 distinct from @xmath77",
    ". then @xmath70 is doubly ruled and hence it is a quadric . thus @xmath80 and hence the generating lines can not form a continuous family .",
    "this contradiction proves the claim .",
    "hereafter any line belonging to the irreducible algebraic curve in @xmath17 containing the generating lines is also called a _",
    "generating line_. no confusion will arise from this .",
    "[ linecross ] if @xmath81 is an irreducible algebraic curve distinct from a generating line then each generating line intersects @xmath82 .",
    "since @xmath83 is ruled it follows that there is a generating line through each point of @xmath82 .",
    "thus infinitely many generating lines belong to @xmath84 . by claim",
    "[ harris](1 ) the set @xmath84 is algebraic , hence the whole irreducible algebraic curve in @xmath17 formed by generating lines is contained in @xmath84 .",
    "[ doesnotcontain ] the surface @xmath73 does not contain the absolute conic .    assume that @xmath72 contains the absolute conic @xmath82 .",
    "then by claim  [ linecross ] all the generating lines intersect @xmath82 .",
    "since @xmath82 has no real points it follows that there are no real generating lines ( except infinitely distant ) .",
    "this contradiction proves the claim .    by claims",
    "[ algebraic ] and  [ doesnotcontain ] the intersection of the surface @xmath73 with the absolute conic is a finite set @xmath85 .",
    "the plane of each generating circle intersects the infinitely distant plane by a line joining two points of the set @xmath85 .",
    "since the set @xmath85 is finite and the family of generating circles is continuous it follows that all these lines coincide , that is , all the planes of the circles are parallel .",
    "[ circleonly ] there are infinitely many generating circles @xmath82 such that the projective plane @xmath86 of @xmath82 intersects the surface @xmath83 only at the points of  @xmath82 .    to prove the lemma , we need the following auxiliary claim .",
    "[ nogenerating ] the projective planes @xmath86 of infinitely many generating circles",
    "@xmath82 do not contain generating lines .",
    "assume that the projective planes of only finitely many generating circles do not contain generating lines .",
    "thus the projective planes @xmath86 of infinitely many generating circles @xmath82 contain generating lines @xmath87 . by lemma  [ parallel ] all the projective planes",
    "@xmath88 intersect the absolute conic by the same @xmath4-point set @xmath89 .",
    "it suffices to consider the following @xmath6 cases .",
    "case 1 : _ for some @xmath82 we have @xmath90_. take a generating circle @xmath91",
    ". then @xmath92 by lemma  [ parallel ] .",
    "then by claim  [ linecross ] we have @xmath93 , a contradiction .",
    "case 2 : _ for infinitely many @xmath82 the intersection @xmath94 consists of a single point_. all the lines @xmath87 with this property are pairwise distinct because by lemma  [ parallel ] they are contained in the planes through @xmath85 .",
    "we get infinitely many generating lines intersecting @xmath85 .",
    "thus by claim  [ algebraic ] _ each _ generating line must intersect @xmath85 .",
    "then the generating lines through each point of a generating circle @xmath82 must intersect @xmath85 , a contradiction .",
    "figure3.png ( 50 , 9 ) @xmath35 ( 46.9 , 28 ) @xmath41 ( 37.5 , 20.5 ) @xmath95 ( 44 , 23.5 ) @xmath96 ( 43 , 14 ) @xmath97 ( 32.6 , 14.8 ) @xmath98    ( 26.9 , 22 ) @xmath57 ( 33 , 26 ) @xmath56 ( 39.6 , 27.6 ) @xmath25    ( 80.2 , 5.3 ) @xmath15    ( 45.8 , 3 ) @xmath87    case 3 : _ for some @xmath82 we have @xmath99 _ ; see figure  [ cl2_7 ] .",
    "then @xmath87 is the infinitely distant line of the projective plane @xmath88 .",
    "since the generating lines form an algebraic curve in @xmath17 it follows that there is a sequence of generating lines @xmath100 converging to @xmath87 . since there are only finitely many generating lines crossing @xmath85 , we may assume that @xmath101 .",
    "take @xmath6 pairwise noncoplanar generating circles @xmath25 , @xmath56 , and @xmath57 . by claim  [ linecross ] for each @xmath102 the line @xmath98 intersects the circle @xmath103 at some point @xmath104 .",
    "each of the @xmath6 points @xmath104 converges to one of the @xmath4 points of the set @xmath85 . by the pigeonhole principle",
    "we may assume that , say , @xmath105 converge to @xmath35 .",
    "then the plane @xmath106 converges to the projective plane @xmath97 containing projective tangent lines to @xmath25 and @xmath56 at the point @xmath35 ( the tangent lines are distinct because @xmath25 and @xmath56 are not coplanar ) .",
    "the projective plane @xmath97 has a unique common point with @xmath25 while @xmath107 intersects @xmath25 by the @xmath4-point set @xmath85 .",
    "this contradiction proves the claim .    by claim  [ nogenerating",
    "] there are infinitely many generating circles @xmath82 such that @xmath108 does not contain generating lines .",
    "then @xmath109 because by claim  [ linecross ] the generating line through each point of @xmath108 crosses @xmath82 .    by lemma  [ circleonly ]",
    "we have @xmath109 for infinitely many generating circles @xmath82 .",
    "so there is a generating circle @xmath82 with this property which is not a singular curve of the surface @xmath72 , because @xmath72 contains only finitely many singular curves . by claim  [ nogenerating ] the plane @xmath88",
    "does not touch the surface @xmath72 along the curve @xmath82 .",
    "thus the circle @xmath82 has multiplicity @xmath5 in the curve @xmath108 . by the bezout theorem ( * ? ? ? * theorem 18.3 ) the degree of the surface @xmath83 equals to the degree of its planar section ( with multiplicity ) , and thus equals to @xmath4 .",
    "since @xmath72 contains both real lines and real circles , it is either a one - sheeted hyperboloid , or a quadratic cone , or an elliptic cylinder .",
    "theorem  [ ruled ] is proved .",
    "in this subsection we prove some related results . throughout this section we work over the field of real numbers except otherwise explicitly indicated . first let us give a simple proof of the following theorem .",
    "[ takeuchi ] let @xmath22 be a smooth closed surface homeomorphic to either a sphere or a torus . if through each point of the surface one can draw at least @xmath11 distinct circles fully contained in the surface ( and continuously depending on the point ) then the surface is a round sphere .    the proof just like the original one is topological .",
    "we simplify the original proof drastically using homology modulo @xmath4 instead of integral homology .",
    "[ topological ] from any @xmath110 smooth closed curves in the surface @xmath55 intersecting pairwise in finitely many points one can choose greater or equal to @xmath111 curves intersecting pairwise in an even number of points ( counted with multiplicities ) .    if @xmath55 is topologically a sphere then any two curves in @xmath55 intersect in an even number of points ( with multiplicities ) , and the claim follows .",
    "assume that @xmath55 is topologically a torus , and @xmath112 and @xmath113 are its `` meridian '' and `` parallel '' curves .",
    "then the 1st homology group of @xmath55 with coefficients modulo @xmath4 consists of @xmath3 homology classes : @xmath114 , @xmath115 $ ] , @xmath116 $ ] , @xmath115+[\\eta]$ ] . by the pigeonhole principle it follows that one of the @xmath6 sets @xmath117\\}$ ] , @xmath118\\}$ ] , @xmath117+[\\eta]\\}$ ] contains the homology classes of greater or equal to @xmath111 of the given @xmath110 curves . since @xmath115\\cap[\\xi]=[\\eta]\\cap[\\eta]= ( [ \\xi]+[\\eta])\\cap ( [ \\xi]+[\\eta])=0 $ ] it follows that the curves from the same set intersect each other in an even number of points .",
    "figure4.png ( 25 , 6 ) @xmath55 ( 51 , 41 ) @xmath35 ( 65 , 43 ) @xmath78 ( 48 , 28 ) @xmath119 ( 60 , 21 ) @xmath120 ( 74 , 43 ) @xmath121 ( 81 , 40 ) @xmath122    [ generic ] two circles passing through a generic point @xmath59 are transversal .",
    "assume that the circles @xmath123 and @xmath124 passing trough the point @xmath35 touch each other ; see figure  [ cl3_3 ] .",
    "move the point @xmath35 slightly along a geodesic in the normal direction to the circles .",
    "draw the circles @xmath120 and @xmath121 through the resulting point @xmath78 of @xmath55 .",
    "then one of the pairs @xmath125 or @xmath126 has @xmath4 distinct intersection points near @xmath35 .",
    "hence there are points arbitrarily close to @xmath35 such that the circles through them are transversal .",
    "the parity of the number of intersection points ( with multiplicities ) does not depend on the choice of particular curves from the families .",
    "thus by claim  [ topological ] there are @xmath6 families @xmath127 , @xmath128 , @xmath129 of circles in @xmath55 such that the circles from distinct families intersect in an even number of points ( with multiplicities ) .",
    "assume without loss of generality that the circles @xmath123 , @xmath124 , @xmath130 pass through a generic point @xmath59 .",
    "then by claim  [ generic ] the circles @xmath123 , @xmath124 , @xmath130 intersect transversally .",
    "then for sufficiently small @xmath131 any two of the circles @xmath123 , @xmath124 , @xmath129 have exactly two common points .",
    "circles with @xmath4 common points are cospherical .",
    "thus @xmath123 and @xmath124 belong to one sphere .",
    "each circle @xmath132 belongs to the same sphere because it has at least @xmath6 common points with the sphere ( @xmath4 pairs of intersection points with @xmath123 and @xmath124 , minus at most @xmath5 common point of the pairs ) . since @xmath55 is a smooth surface , it can not jump from one sphere to another .",
    "thus @xmath55 is a sphere itself ; cf .",
    "* theorem  1 ) .",
    "now let us prove a new result generalizing an old one of darboux .",
    "[ 3families ] let @xmath22 be a smooth closed surface homeomorphic to either a sphere or a torus .",
    "if through each point of the surface one can draw at least @xmath3 distinct circles fully contained in the surface ( and continuously depending on the point ) then the surface is a cyclide .",
    "let @xmath127 , @xmath128 , @xmath129 , @xmath133 be the @xmath3 families of circles in the surface @xmath55 .",
    "assume without loss of generality that the circles @xmath123 , @xmath124 , @xmath130 , @xmath134 pass through a generic point @xmath35 .",
    "since @xmath55 is topologically either a sphere or a torus by  claim  [ topological ] it follows that we can choose @xmath4 families , say , @xmath127 and @xmath128 , such that for each @xmath135 the circles @xmath127 and @xmath136 have an even number of intersection points ( with multiplicities ) . by claim  [ generic ] the circles @xmath123 and @xmath124 are transversal .",
    "thus for @xmath137 , @xmath131 sufficiently close to zero the circles @xmath127 and @xmath136 are cospherical .",
    "now the theorem follows from the following classical result .",
    "[ cospherical ] if through each point of a smooth surface in @xmath2 one can draw @xmath4 cospherical circular arcs fully contained in the surface ( and continuously depending on the point ) then the surface is a cyclide .",
    "[ sketch of the proof ] the surface is covered by two families of circular arcs @xmath127 and @xmath128 .",
    "fix a sphere @xmath138 orthogonal to both @xmath139 and @xmath140 .",
    "take the spheres @xmath141 and @xmath142 containing @xmath143 and @xmath144 , respectively . since @xmath145 it follows that @xmath146 .",
    "analogously , @xmath147 .",
    "if @xmath148 for each @xmath131 then @xmath55 is a sphere through the circles @xmath139 and @xmath140 .",
    "otherwise @xmath149 for each @xmath131 .",
    "analogously @xmath150 for each @xmath131 .",
    "assume without loss of generality that @xmath138 is the unit sphere .",
    "perform the _ darboux transformation _",
    "@xmath151 taking all circles orthogonal to @xmath138 to line segments .",
    "the transformation takes our surface to a doubly ruled surface .",
    "thus our surface is the preimage of a quadric under the darboux transformation , i.e. , a cyclide .",
    "now let us give examples showing nontriviality of our results .",
    "we begin with examples over the field of complex numbers .",
    "[ ex1 ] the irreducible complex cyclide @xmath152 , which can be parametrized in @xmath13 as @xmath153 , is covered by a family of complex lines @xmath154 and a family of complex circles @xmath155 simultaneously .",
    "[ ex3 ] a general position degree @xmath6 complex cyclide is covered by a family of complex circles and contains @xmath156 complex lines ; however , the surface contains no families of complex lines .",
    "any cyclide is covered by at least one family of complex circles ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter  vii ) .",
    "a general position degree @xmath6 cyclide is nonsingular and hence contains exactly @xmath156 complex lines .",
    "[ ex2 ] a general position ruled complex cubic surface is covered by a family of complex lines and contains @xmath157 complex circles ; however , the surface contains no families of complex circles .",
    "consider the intersection @xmath85 of the ruled cubic surface with the absolute conic .",
    "in general position it consists of six distinct points .",
    "let @xmath35 , @xmath41 be two of the intersection points .",
    "let @xmath158 be the line passing through @xmath35 , @xmath41 , and let @xmath159 be the third common point of @xmath158 and the surface . in general position @xmath160 .",
    "consider the ruling @xmath161 passing through @xmath159 .",
    "take the plane @xmath88 containing the lines @xmath158 and @xmath161 .",
    "the intersection of @xmath88 and the surface consists of the ruling @xmath161 and a curve @xmath82 of degree @xmath4 .",
    "the curve @xmath82 is irreducible once the plane @xmath88 contains neither the singular line nor the isolated line of the surface , i.e. , the points @xmath35 , @xmath41 , @xmath159 do not belong to these lines ( this follows from the classification of ruled cubic surfaces ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 2 ) ) .",
    "thus in general position @xmath82 is a conic through @xmath35 and @xmath41 , i.e. , a complex circle .",
    "there are @xmath157 ways to choose two distinct points @xmath162 leading to @xmath157 complex circles on the surface .",
    "finally , let us proceed to examples over the field of real numbers .",
    "their obvious proofs are omitted .",
    "[ ex5 ] ( see figure  [ fig - examples ] to the left . ) the surface @xmath163 is covered by a family of circles in the planes @xmath164 and contains @xmath3 lines : @xmath165 , @xmath166 , @xmath167 , @xmath168 ; however , the surface contains no families of lines .",
    "[ ex4 ] ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  1 ) and figure  [ fig - examples ] in the middle . ) the surface @xmath169 obtained by translation of a circle along another one is covered by @xmath4 families of circles in the planes @xmath170 and @xmath164 but it is not a cyclide .",
    "it is not known so far if there are surfaces covered by @xmath6 families of circles besides cyclides .",
    "let us give a related counterexample from _ isotropic geometry _",
    "isotropic circle _ is either a parabola with the axis parallel to  @xmath171 or an ellipse whose projection into the plane @xmath172 is a circle .",
    "an _ isotropic cyclide _ is given by equation  , in which both instances of @xmath173 are replaced by @xmath174 ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  5 ) .",
    "[ ex6 ] ( see figure  [ fig - examples ] to the right . ) the surface @xmath175 is covered by @xmath6 families of isotropic circles in the planes @xmath176 , @xmath170 , @xmath177 but it is not an isotropic cyclide .",
    "family of circles and containing @xmath3 lines ( example  [ ex5 ] ) .",
    "middle : a surface covered by @xmath4 families of circles ( example  [ ex4 ] ) .",
    "right : a surface covered by @xmath6 families of isotropic circles ( example  [ ex6]).,title=\"fig:\",scaledwidth=36.0% ] family of circles and containing @xmath3 lines ( example  [ ex5 ] ) .",
    "middle : a surface covered by @xmath4 families of circles ( example  [ ex4 ] ) . right : a surface covered by @xmath6 families of isotropic circles ( example  [ ex6]).,title=\"fig:\",scaledwidth=24.0% ]   family of circles and containing @xmath3 lines ( example  [ ex5 ] ) .",
    "middle : a surface covered by @xmath4 families of circles ( example  [ ex4 ] ) .",
    "right : a surface covered by @xmath6 families of isotropic circles ( example  [ ex6]).,title=\"fig:\",scaledwidth=22.0% ]",
    "the authors are grateful to s.  gusein - zade , r.  krasauskas , h.  pottmann , i.  sabitov for useful discussions and to l.  shi for the first figure .",
    "r. krasauskas , s. zube , bezier - like parametrizations of spheres and cyclides using geometric algebra . in : k.",
    "guerlebeck ( ed . ) , proceedings of 9th international conference on clifford algebras and their applications in mathematical physics , weimar , germany , 2011 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we prove that a surface in 3-dimensional euclidean space containing a line and a circle through each point is a quadric . </S>",
    "<S> we also give some particular results on the classification of surfaces containing several circles through each point .    </S>",
    "<S> * keywords * : ruled surface , circular surface , circle , cyclide , conic bundle .    * </S>",
    "<S> 2010 msc * : 14j26 , 51m04 . </S>"
  ]
}
